question: In the context of food preparation before swallowing, which part of the mouth assists in making food ready for digestion?
gold_answer: The mouth helps to prepare food.
llm_answer: The saliva in the mouth assists in making food ready for digestion by mixing with the food and changing starch into sugar.

context.text: is dry and tasteless. Soon, however, you find it tastes sweet; the saliva is changing the starch into sugar. All your food should be eaten slowly and chewed well, so that the saliva may be able to mix with it. Otherwise, the starch may not be changed; and if one part of your body neglects its work, another part will have more than its share to do. That is hardly fair. If you swallow your food in a hurry and do not let the saliva do its work, the stomach will have extra work. But it will find it hard to do more than its own part, and, perhaps, will complain. It can not speak in words; but will by aching, and that is almost as plain as words. SWALLOWING. Next to the chewing, comes the swallowing. Is there any thing wonderful about that? We have two passages leading down our throats. One is to the lungs, for breathing; the other, to the stomach, for swallowing. Do you wonder why the food does not sometimes go down the wrong way? The windpipe leading to the lungs is in front of the other tube. It has at its top a little trap-door. This opens when we breathe and shuts when we swallow, so that the food slips over it safely into the passage behind, which leads to the stomach. If you try to speak while you have food in your mouth, this little door has to open, and some bit of food may

because they do not put any in. But you know that the alcohol is made in the fruit-juice itself by the change of the sugar into alcohol and the gas. [Illustration] It is the nature of alcohol to make the person who takes a little of it, in wine, or any other drink, want more and more alcohol. When one goes on, thus taking more and more of the drinks that contain alcohol, he is called a drunkard. In this way wine has made many drunkards. Alcohol hurts both the body and mind. It changes the person who drinks it. It will make a good and kind person cruel and bad; and will make a bad person worse. Every one who takes wine does not become a drunkard, but you are not sure that you will not, if you drink it. You should not drink wine, because there is alcohol in it. CIDER. Cider is made from apples. In a few hours after the juice is pressed out of the apples, if it is left open to the air the sugar begins to change. Like the sugar in the grape, it changes into alcohol and bubbles of gas. At first, there is but little alcohol in cider, but a little of this poison is dangerous. More alcohol is all the time forming until in ten cups of cider there may be one cup of alcohol. Cider often makes its drinkers ill-tempered and cross. Cider and wine will turn into vinegar if left in a

one cup of alcohol. Cider often makes its drinkers ill-tempered and cross. Cider and wine will turn into vinegar if left in a warm place long enough. REVIEW QUESTIONS.           1. What two things are in all fruit-juices?           2. How can we tell the juice of grapes from that           of plums?           3. How can we tell the juice of apples from that           of cherries?           4. What is often done with ripe grapes?           5. What happens after the grape-juice has stood a           short time?           6. Why would the changed grape-juice not be good           to use in making jelly?           7. Into what is the sugar in the juice changed?           8. What becomes of the gas?           9. What becomes of the alcohol?

How can you prove that saliva turns starch into           sugar?           10. What happens if the food is not chewed and           mixed with the saliva?           11. What comes next to the chewing?           12. What is there wonderful about swallowing?           13. What must you be careful about, when you are           swallowing?           14. What happens to the food after it is           swallowed?           15. How is it changed in the stomach?           16. What carries the food to every part of the           body?           17. How can food mend a bone? CHAPTER XIII. STRENGTH. [Illustration: H]ERE are the names of some of the different kinds of food. If you write them on the blackboard or on your slates, it will help you to remember them.

to make jelly, she would say: "Now, I can not make my grape-jelly, for the grape-juice is spoiled." WHAT IS THIS CHANGE IN THE GRAPE-JUICE? The sugar in the grape-juice is changing into something else. It is turning into alcohol and a gas[A] that moves about in little bubbles in the liquid, and rising to the top, goes off into the air. The alcohol is a thin liquid which, mixed with the water, remains in the grape-juice. The sugar is gone; alcohol and the bubbles of gas are left in its place. This alcohol is a liquid poison. A little of it will harm any one who drinks it; much of it would kill the drinker. Ripe grapes are good food; but grape-juice, when its sugar has turned to alcohol, is not a safe drink for any one. It is poisoned by the alcohol. WINE. This changed grape-juice is called wine. It is partly water, partly alcohol, and it still has the grape flavor in it. Wine is also made from currants, elderberries, and other fruits, in very much the same way as from grapes. People sometimes make it at home from the fruits that grow in their own gardens, and think there is no alcohol in it, because they do not put any in. But you know that the alcohol is made in the fruit-juice itself by the change of the sugar

the body which need it, comes from fat-making foods. In cold weather, we need more fatty food than we do in summer, just as in cold countries people need such food all the time. The Esquimaux, who live in the lands of snow and ice, catch a great many walrus and seal, and eat a great deal of fat meat. You would not be well unless you ate some fat or butter or oil. WHAT WILL MAKE FAT? Sugar will make fat, and so will starch, cream, rice, butter, and fat meat. As milk will make muscle and fat and bones, it is the best kind of food. Here, again, it is the earth that sends us our food. Fat meat comes from animals well fed on grain and grass; sugar, from sugar-cane, maple-trees, or beets; oil, from olive-trees; butter, from cream; and starch, from potatoes, and from corn, rice, and other grains. Green apples and other unripe fruits are not yet ready to be eaten. The starch which we take for food has to be changed into sugar, before it can mix with the blood and help feed the body. As the sun ripens fruit, it changes its starch to sugar. You can tell this by the difference in the taste of ripe and unripe apples. CANDY. Most children like candy so well, that they are in danger of eating more sugar than is good for them.

the upper edge of the opening should be level with the lower side of the sweep of the fan blade, somewhat as shown in Fig. 5. [Illustration: FIG. 5] A considerable number of patents has been taken out for improvements in the construction of fans, but they all, or nearly all, relate to modifications in the form of the case and of the blades. So far, however, as is known, it appears that, while these things do exert a marked influence on the noise made by a fan, and modify in some degree the efficiency of the machine, that this last depends very much more on the proportions adopted than on the shapes--so long as easy curves are used and sharp angles avoided. In the case of fans running at low speeds, it matters very little whether the curves are present or not; but at high speeds the case is different.--_The Engineer_. MACHINE FOR COMPRESSING COAL REFUSE INTO FUEL. The problem as to how the refuse of coal shall be utilized has been solved in the manufacture from it of an agglomerated artificial fuel, which is coming more and more into general use on railways and steamboats, in the industries, and even in domestic heating. The qualities that a good agglomerating machine should present are as follows: 1. Very great simplicity, inasmuch as it is called upon to operate in an atmosphere charged with coal dust, pitch, and steam; and, under such conditions, it is

to the stomach. If you try to speak while you have food in your mouth, this little door has to open, and some bit of food may slip in. The windpipe will not pass it to the lungs, but tries to force it back. Then we say the food chokes us. If the windpipe can not succeed in forcing back the food, the person will die. HOW THE FOOD IS CARRIED THROUGH THE BODY. But we will suppose that the food of our dinner has gone safely down into the stomach. There the stomach works it over, and mixes in gastric juice, until it is all a gray fluid. Now it is ready to go into the intestines,--a long, coiled tube which leads out of the stomach,--from which the prepared food is taken into the blood. The blood carries it to the heart. The heart pumps it out with the blood into the lungs, and then all through the body, to make bone, and muscle, and skin, and hair, and eyes, and brain. Besides feeding all these parts, this dinner can help to mend any parts that may be broken. Suppose a boy should break one of the bones of his arm, how could it be mended? If you should bind together the two parts of a broken stick and leave them a while, do you think they would grow together? No, indeed! But the doctor could carefully bind together the ends of the broken bone in the boy's arm and leave

Mr. Buckle is one of the very few authorities on the subject. He gives the accompanying table of proportions as the best for pressures of from 3 to 6 ounces per square inch: -------------------------------------------------------------- | Vanes. | Diameter of inlet Diameter of fans. |------------------------| openings. | Width. | Length. | -------------------------------------------------------------- ft. in. | ft. in. | ft. in. | ft. in. 3 0 | 0 9 | 0 9 | 1 6 3 6 | 0 101/2 | 0 101/2 | 1 9 4 0 | 1 0 | 1 0 | 2 0 4 6 | 1 11/2 | 1 11/2 | 2 3 5 0 | 1 3 | 1 3 | 2 6 6 0 | 1 6 | 1 6 | 3 0 | | | -------------------------------------------------------------- For higher pressures the blades should be longer and narrower, and the inlet openings smaller. The case is to be made in the form of an arithmetical spiral widening, the space between the case and the blades radially from the origin to the opening for discharge, and the upper edge of the opening should be level with the lower side of the sweep of the fan blade, somewhat as shown in Fig. 5.

communities.summary:
1. **Title**: Natural History and Human Nutrition
2. **Summary**: The provided text chunks discuss various topics related to natural history, including the discovery of a new bird species, the Ocellated Pheasant, and its characteristics. Additionally, the chunks touch on human nutrition, exploring the idea that humans are naturally frugivorous and discussing the adaptability of the human digestive system to different food sources. The texts also mention the importance of understanding the utilization of food for bodily functions and the classification of substances as food or non-food. The discussion on bird species and human nutrition seems to be the main theme, with some chunks providing detailed descriptions of the Ocellated Pheasant's physical characteristics and others delving into the history of human dietary habits.
3. **Keywords**: Ocellated Pheasant, Human Nutrition, Natural History, Bird Species, Frugivorous Diet

1. **Diary of Samuel Pepys**
2. **Summary**: The diary entries of Samuel Pepys describe his daily activities, social interactions, and personal experiences in 17th-century England. He attends the theatre, visits friends and family, and participates in social gatherings, often involving food, drink, and merriment. Pepys also mentions his work at the office and his interactions with prominent figures, including Sir William Batten and Captain Ferrers. The entries provide insight into Pepys' personal life, relationships, and the cultural and social context of his time. He also records significant events, such as a general fast to be kept in London and the country, and the assembly of the High Court of Parliament.
3. **Keywords**: Samuel Pepys, 17th century, Diary, London, Social Life

1. **Title**: Industrial Machinery and Innovations
2. **Summary**: The collection of text chunks discusses various industrial machinery and innovations, including improved gas engines, bone-black revivifying plants, and hank sizing machines. These machines are designed to increase efficiency and productivity in different industries, such as manufacturing and textiles. The texts also describe the technical details of these machines, including their components, mechanisms, and operating principles. Additionally, some texts mention the potential applications and benefits of these innovations, such as improving the quality of drinking water and enabling the production of certain goods.
3. **Keywords**: Industrial Machinery, Innovations, Manufacturing, Textiles, Gas Engines

1. **Title**: Effects of Alcohol Consumption
2. **Summary**: The provided text chunks discuss the negative effects of alcohol consumption on the human body. Alcohol is formed through the fermentation of sugar in fruit juices, such as grape and apple, and can be found in drinks like wine and cider. Consuming alcohol can lead to addiction, harm the body and mind, and even cause death. The texts also touch on the importance of a healthy diet and the role of different food groups in maintaining a strong body. Additionally, the dangers of tobacco use and the importance of avoiding harmful substances are mentioned. Overall, the texts emphasize the need for responsible behavior and healthy habits to maintain overall well-being.
3. **Keywords**: Alcohol, Addiction, Health, Nutrition, Tobacco

1. **Title**: Land's End Experience
2. **Summary**: The authors describe their visit to the Land's End, a remote peninsula in Great Britain, where they experience a mix of challenges and serene moments. Initially, they face difficulties with food and accommodations, but eventually, they find comfort and peace in the First and Last Inn. As they explore the area, they are struck by the vastness and power of the sea, which evokes feelings of awe and contemplation. The authors reflect on the unique experience of spending a Sunday at the Land's End, surrounded by intense solitude and silence, and how it allows them to glimpse the concept of infinity. Despite the initial struggles, they find the experience exhilarating and wish they had more time to explore the area.
3. **Keywords**: Land's End, Solitude, Infinity, Sea, Exploration

1. **Title**: Perche District Mining Excitement
2. **Summary**: The Perche district has experienced significant mining excitement due to the discovery of rich silver deposits, with many prospectors flocking to the area. The district has seen numerous strikes, including the notable Solitaire mine, which showed promising results but was later reported to be a blind lead. Despite this, the area remains a hub of mining activity, with many mines and prospects being developed. The region's mining fever has drawn in investors and prospectors, with some notable figures, such as Governor Tabor, showing interest in the area. The human body's resistance to heat is also discussed, with experiments demonstrating the ability to withstand high temperatures using protective gear. Additionally, the Soy bean is mentioned as a valuable food source, rich in fat and albuminoids.
3. **Keywords**: Perche District, Mining, Silver, Prospecting, Heat Resistance

1. **Title**: Photographic Water Purification
2. **Summary**: The collection of text chunks discusses the importance of using pure water in photography, particularly in the preparation of emulsion and development processes. It highlights the need for distilled water and describes various methods for obtaining and purifying water, including the use of rainwater, filters, and distillation apparatus. The chunks also touch on the topic of black phosphorus and its properties, as well as other unrelated topics such as cider production and bone-black revivification. However, the primary focus is on the purification of water for photographic use.
3. **Keywords**: Water Purification, Photography, Distillation, Rainwater, Filtration

1. **Classical Love and Poetry**
2. **Summary**: The text chunks discuss themes of love, poetry, and classical literature, with references to Roman mythology and the works of Ovid. The author reflects on the nature of love and relationships, using metaphors and allusions to convey their thoughts. The chunks also touch on the idea of artistic expression, with the poet deliberating between writing elegies and tragedies. The language is lyrical and expressive, with a focus on the emotional and personal aspects of love and creativity.
3. **Keywords**: Classical Literature, Love Poetry, Roman Mythology, Ovid, Elegies

1. **Title**: Health and Substance Abuse
2. **Summary**: The provided text chunks discuss the importance of maintaining good health, particularly during childhood and adolescence. They warn against the dangers of substance abuse, such as tobacco and alcohol, which can have severe and long-lasting effects on the body. The chunks also provide guidance on how to care for various parts of the body, including the eyes, ears, and spine, and emphasize the need for healthy habits and responsible decision-making. The overall theme is one of promoting healthy lifestyles and warning against the risks associated with substance abuse. The text also highlights the importance of self-care and responsible behavior, particularly during childhood and adolescence, in order to maintain good physical and mental health.
3. **Keywords**: Health, Substance Abuse, Tobacco, Alcohol, Wellness

1. **Title**: Love and Redemption
2. **Summary**: The text chunks revolve around two main storylines: the blossoming romance between Young Latimer and Ellen, and the struggles of a burglar who has escaped from jail. The bishop, Ellen's father, is initially hesitant about the relationship but eventually warms up to Latimer. Meanwhile, the burglar, who is desperate to reunite with his family, is shown kindness by Van Bibber, who decides to help him instead of turning him in. The stories explore themes of love, redemption, and the complexities of human relationships. The characters' emotions and motivations are deeply intertwined, leading to a nuanced and empathetic portrayal of their experiences. Through their journeys, the text highlights the importance of understanding, compassion, and the power of human connection.
3. **Keywords**: Romance, Redemption, Family, Love, Forgiveness
